Maps created with Cartopy99.Full size imageUnder RCP4.5, lower greenhouse gas forcing limits the AIS GMSLR contribution to 0.13 m by 2100 with 0.1 m from WAIS and 0.03 m from EAIS (Fig. 1e, Supplementary Table 1). The pattern of ice loss mirrors that of RCP8.5 with Thwaites Glacier retreating and Ronne-Filchner thinning, but ice shelf thinning is less extensive overall, particularly in the EAIS (Fig. 1a). By 2200 the AIS GMSLR contribution reaches 1.17 m with 0.97 m from WAIS and 0.2 m from EAIS (Fig. 1f, Supplementary Table 1). The long-term view shows the impact of reducing greenhouse gas forcing; while WAIS still retreats substantially, large sections of the EAIS and portions of the Antarctic peninsula remain intact under RCP4.5 thereby limiting the AIS contribution to GMSLR.Polar climate responseAs CESM has static ice sheet topography, while PSU3D has evolving ice sheet topography, air temperatures noted here represent advected changes from evolving ocean conditions and do not reflect changes in the local land surface within CESM. In our coupled RCP8.5 experiment, surface air temperature (SAT) increases ~2–4 °C by 2100 across the Southern Ocean and AIS (Fig. 2a). Regionally, this is ~1–4 °C cooler than the uncoupled simulation (Fig. 2b). By the end of the 22nd century, there is widespread 5–10 °C warming across the ice sheet, especially in the Ross and Weddell Sea regions, although this is up to ~7 °C cooler than the uncoupled control simulation across the coastal region (Supplementary Fig. 2a, b). Under RCP4.5, SAT increases by ~1-2 °C by 2100 in the coupled simulation, except in the region of the Ross Sea where temperatures are lower by the end of 2100 and 2200 as compared to the start of the simulation (Supplementary Figs. 3a, 4a). Compared to the uncoupled simulation, SAT is ~1 °C cooler by 2100, although the coupled simulation is slightly warmer in a few locations (Supplementary Fig. 3b). By 2200 the cooler temperatures in the coupled simulation as compared to the control are more pronounced with the largest difference in the Ross Sea (Supplementary Fig. 4b).Fig. 2: Southern Ocean climate change by 2100 for RCP8.5.a Southern Ocean surface air temperature (SAT) change in the coupled simulation during the 21st century, b The SAT difference between the coupled and control simulations averaged over the last 30 years of the 21st century, c same as (a) but for precipitation, d same as (b) but for precipitation, e same as (a) but for 400 m ocean temperatures, f same as (b) but for 400 m ocean temperatures. Maps created with Cartopy99 with colormaps from100.Full size imageThroughout the RCP8.5 simulation, precipitation over the Southern Ocean increases (Fig. 2c; Supplementary Fig. 2c), although this change is less than in the uncoupled simulation (Fig. 2d; Supplementary Fig. 2d). The same overall patterns are found in RCP4.5 except the coupled simulation has slightly more precipitation than the control around Queen Maud and Wilkes Land by 2100 (Supplementary Fig. 3c, d). By 2200, precipitation in the coupled simulation has increased (Supplementary Fig. 4c) but is consistently lower in the RCP4.5 coupled simulation compared to the control (Supplementary Fig. 4d).By 2100, under RCP8.5, ocean temperatures at 400 m depth warm substantially across the Southern Ocean (Fig. 2e), driven by freshwater-induced stratification and reduced vertical mixing. The greatest warming is in the Weddell Sea, with a 3 °C temperature rise compared to the start of the simulation; the Ross Sea and EAIS margin near Wilkes Land warm by ~1 °C. The end of century difference between the coupled and control simulations (Fig. 2f), as compared to the warming over time in the coupled simulation (Fig. 2e), shows that much of the warming is due to meltwater forcing. By 2200, 400 m ocean temperatures show widespread ~2 °C warming relative to the start of the simulation (Supplementary Fig. 2e), with the Ross Sea ~4 °C warmer in the coupled simulation than the control (Supplementary Fig. 2f). Under RCP4.5, the Weddell Sea and region around Wilkes Land are 3 °C and 1 °C warmer, respectively, by 2100 (Supplementary Fig. 3e). As in RCP8.5, much of this warming is due to the impact of meltwater (Supplementary Fig. 3f). By 2200 in RCP4.5, warming intensifies with ~2 °C warming across the Southern Ocean since the start of the simulation (Supplementary Fig. 4e) and temperatures in the Ross and Weddell Seas up to 4 °C higher in the coupled simulation than the control (Supplementary Fig. 4f).The impacts of these climatic changes on the ice sheet explain the mass loss and contribution to GMSLR. Increases in SAT drive surface melt and induce hydrofracturing and ice shelf thinning while the accumulated ocean heat (i.e., warming at 400 m) increases basal melt under buttressing ice shelves. The concentration of heat in the Ross and Weddell Seas flips cold ice-shelf cavity circulation to warm cavity circulation patterns, accelerating loss of the large ice shelves, triggering MISI and in some places, ice cliff calving.Global climate responseOur coupled simulations show that the impacts of AIS discharge into the Southern Ocean are felt globally (Fig. 3). In both RCP4.5 and RCP8.5, freshwater forcing begins suppressing greenhouse gas induced GMST rise by the middle of the 21st century (Fig. 3c). Under RCP8.5, GMST is 0.33 °C lower by 2100 and 1.05°C lower by 2200 in the coupled simulation than in the control (Fig. 3d; Table 1). Under RCP4.5, GMST in the coupled simulation is 0.29°C lower by 2100 and 0.31°C lower by 2200 than in the control (Fig. 3d, Table 1). Compared to prior uncoupled experiments with the same models26, the impact of Antarctic meltwater on GMST is reduced due to the delayed ice sheet mass loss, and, therefore, lower meltwater input, that results from the interactive coupling.Fig. 3: Effect of Antarctic meltwater input on future climate.a The difference between the 2 m surface air temperature (SAT) in the RCP8.5 coupled experiment versus the control by the end of the century (2070-2099). b Same as (a) for RCP4.5. c Global mean surface temperature (GMST) above the 1850–1900 average with horizontal lines marking 1.5°, 2°, and 3 °C. d A time series of the temperature difference between the coupled and control simulations. e Difference in precipitation between the RCP8.5 coupled and control simulations at the end of the century. f Same as (e) for RCP4.5. g Zonal mean precipitation under the control simulations. h Same as (g) for the difference between the coupled and control simulations. Maps created with Cartopy99 with colormaps from101.Full size imageTable 1 Projected global mean sea level and air temperature riseFull size tableThe delayed GMST warming resulting from Southern Ocean freshwater forcing in our coupled simulations is caused by both a stronger ocean heat uptake efficiency (i.e., more efficient heat storage in the subsurface ocean) and a stronger atmospheric radiative feedback (i.e., more efficient radiative damping at the top of the atmosphere) (ref.42; See Methods). The former is owing to the increased ocean stratification and vertical heat redistribution in the Southern Ocean manifested as subsurface warming (Fig. 2f). The latter is due to the broad surface cooling in both the Southern Ocean and the tropical Pacific driven by freshwater forcing and large-scale teleconnections (Supplementary Fig. 6)42,43,44. The Southern Ocean cooling anomalies and sea-ice expansion locally enhance surface albedo feedback, whereas the tropical East Pacific surface cooling drives a more-stabilizing cloud feedback and lapse-rate feedback, resulting from the strengthened tropical west-east zonal sea surface temperature gradient45,46. The net radiative feedback parameter over the 21st century is therefore strengthened from −1.02 W/m²/K to −1.13 W/m²/K in the coupled RCP8.5 simulation, corresponding to a 0.4°C decrease in effective climate sensitivity (from 3.8°C to 3.4°C) relative to the uncoupled control simulation. The results are qualitatively consistent with the findings in our prior uncoupled freshwater forcing simulations26,42.Although GMST increases at a slower rate compared to our control simulations, the coupled simulations exhibit strong regional SAT variations (Fig. 3a, b). For example, by 2100 in RCP8.5, surface air temperatures over the Southern Ocean are ~1–1.5°C cooler, central and east Asia and the North Pacific are 0.3 °C warmer, and the North Atlantic, including Greenland, eastern North America and western Europe are 1-2°C warmer than in the uncoupled simulation (Fig. 3a). By 2200 in RCP8.5 (Supplementary Fig. 5a), anomalous cooling over the Southern Ocean continues, with temperatures >3°C cooler in the coupled experiment near the Antarctic continent. By 2100 under RCP4.5 the difference between the coupled and control experiments shows a bipolar temperature pattern with anomalous cooling in the Southern Hemisphere and anomalous warming in the Northern Hemisphere but the pattern differs from that seen in RCP8.5 with no strong warming over the North Atlantic and instead more diffuse warming across Asia, North Africa, and the Pacific Ocean (Fig. 3b). By 2200 in RCP4.5, anomalous cooling of ~1°C occurs over the Southern Ocean and Arctic with slight warming across much of the Northern Hemisphere and the most pronounced warming of ~0.5°C along the Pacific coast of North America (Supplementary Fig. 5c).The higher temperatures in the North Atlantic and North Pacific point to the existence of a bipolar seesaw, a pattern previously identified in Southern Ocean freshwater forcing experiments43,47,48. In RCP8.5, future slowing of the Atlantic Meridional Overturning Circulation (AMOC), defined as the maximum overturning at 24-26°N, is found to be largely delayed (Fig. 4a). In the coupled RCP8.5 simulation, the AMOC remains stronger than in the control from 2075 until the end of the simulation. The maximum difference between AMOC strength in the two simulations occurs at 2100 when the strongest signal of enhanced warming in both air (Fig. 3b) and sea surface temperatures (Supplementary Fig. 6) is observed in the coupled simulation. In RCP4.5, both the coupled and control simulations exhibit initial AMOC weakening followed by a partial recovery beginning after 2125. Under RCP4.5 whether the coupled or control simulation shows stronger AMOC strength is variable over time (Fig. 4a). In addition, northward heat transport is found to decrease under both RCP8.5 and RCP4.5 forcing (Fig. 4b). The largest differences occur at low-to-mid northern latitudes where the Atlantic Ocean is most effective at transporting heat northward.Fig. 4: Change in overturning circulation strength and northward heat transport due to coupling.a Meridional overturning circulation (MOC) strength in the Atlantic Ocean for the coupled and control simulations under RCP8.5 and RCP4.5, b northward heat transport in the Atlantic Ocean averaged over the period 2070-2099.Full size imageCoupled meltwater simulations under both RCP8.5 and RCP4.5 show a robust northward shift of the intertropical convergence zone, due to zonal-mean energetic constraints associated with the anomalous inter-hemispheric surface temperature gradient49. In the Southern Hemisphere, wide-spread surface cooling is accompanied with broad drying while in the Northern Hemisphere, precipitation generally increases (Fig. 3 and Supplementary Fig. 5), which may arise from both local temperature changes or remote tropical teleconnections50. Under RCP8.5, zonal mean precipitation in the control simulation changes little over time (Fig. 3g) while in the coupled simulation it enhances north of the equator and diminishes to the south (Fig. 3h).Broader Implications of Antarctic Ice LossAntarctic mass loss has important implications for people around the world. Fully understanding the potential impact of Antarctica’s contribution to sea level necessitates analyzing the spatial pattern of the sea level response. Global sea level change patterns from ice sheet mass loss are spatially variable due to gravitational, rotational, and Earth deformational (GRD) effects51. Using a 3D viscoelastic Earth structure model (See Methods) which includes anomalously low viscosities under the WAIS allows us to account for the sea level impact of water expulsion into the open ocean from formerly ice-covered areas undergoing uplift due to glacial isostatic adjustment52. Patterns of sea level change from GRD effects vary spatially and temporally depending on the regions of Antarctic mass loss21,51. Consistent with prior research10,21 we find that regions northward of 30°S will experience sea level rise higher than the Antarctic contribution to GMSLR regardless of emissions scenario and timescales. However, the most heavily impacted regions vary (Fig. 5). Under RCP4.5 by 2100 the Indian, Pacific, and Atlantic Ocean basins, including the Caribbean, experience 0.03 m higher regional sea level rise than the global mean (Fig. 5a). By 2200 the pattern is similar but the difference between the highest impacted regions increases by an order of magnitude to 0.3 m (Fig. 5c). Under RCP8.5 by 2100, most of the Pacific basin is projected to experience regional sea level rise of up to 0.09 m higher than the GMSLR of 0.34 m (Fig. 5b). This pattern remains at 2200 with areas in the central Pacific experiencing 0.9 m more regional sea level rise than the GMSLR of 3.37 m while the Indian and Atlantic Ocean basins experience 0.6 and 0.7 m higher regional sea levels, respectively (Fig. 5d). These regional changes are solely based on the Antarctic response but realized sea level would also depend on Greenland mass loss, thermosteric responses, and other factors which are not accounted for here21,53.Fig. 5: Spatial change in sea level resulting from projected Antarctic ice sheet mass loss.a The spatial pattern of sea level change resulting from gravitational, rotational, and Earth deformational effects at 2100 under RCP4.5. The purple band designates the global mean sea level contribution from the Antarctic ice sheet. b same as (a) for RCP8.5. c same as (a) for 2200. d same as (b) for 2200. Maps created with ArcGIS using Natural Earth land boundaries.Full size imageContrasting the global sea level response to the influence of meltwater on GMST has implications for global mitigation efforts and climate (in)justice10. Under RCP8.5, the timing when GMST exceeds 1.5–2°C above preindustrial (defined here following IPCC AR6 as when the 20-year rolling mean exceeds 1.5–2°C above the 1850–1900 average) is minimally affected by the meltwater induced delay in GMST rise (Supplementary Fig. 7a). This is because these warming values are surpassed before the meltwater-induced delayed warming effect strengthens. In our simulations, under high emissions (RCP8.5) 1.5°C is passed by 2026 and 2°C is delayed by 1 year in the coupled simulation. Under RCP4.5, 1.5°C and 2°C are each delayed by 1 year in the coupled simulation (Supplementary Fig. 7b). Given that these are single model runs with one set of models, how meltwater effects and other climate feedbacks impact the timing of different temperature thresholds remains deeply uncertain.While the timing of the Long-Term Temperature Goal is minimally impacted, the long-term difference in GMST when accounting for meltwater input and feedbacks is substantial (Table 1) and relevant for informing future global mitigation target setting. The strength of the delayed GMST warming that occurs from Antarctic meltwater forcing should be considered alongside other climate feedbacks, such as the anticipated enhanced warming effect of permafrost melt. The combined impacts of climatic changes that influence GMST with other impacts such as sea level rise could pose substantial challenges if a GMST-based metric was used to inform international policy post-210010. In this study we find that GMST is 1.05 °C lower under RCP8.5 by 2200 in the coupled simulation compared to the control, but this relatively cooler climate trajectory is commensurate with an Antarctic GMSLR contribution of 3.37 m and regional sea level rise of up to 4.3 m in the Pacific (Fig. 5d). Under RCP4.5, GMST is 0.31°C lower in the coupled simulation by 2200 while Antarctica’s contribution to GMSLR is 1.17 m and regional sea level rise of up to 1.5 m occurs in the Pacific and Indian Ocean basins and Caribbean Sea (Fig. 5c). In other words, while the loss of ice sheet mass results in a slightly lower GMST rise in the coupled simulations, it drives substantial sea level rise. This supports previous work which has argued that focusing on GMST as a metric to inform climate action could exacerbate climate justice concerns10. Even with a slower rate of warming, any continued increase in sea level poses risks to island and coastal communities, and raises wide-ranging issues of intergenerational inequity and distributive injustice10. The implications for justice and policy are complex and influenced by many other factors that require further detailed study.DiscussionHere we have modeled the impacts of Antarctic ice sheet discharge on climate and sea level using an ice sheet model and climate model in interactive coupling, combined with sea level fingerprint modeling to understand the global patterns of sea level change resulting from ice sheet mass loss. We find that projected rates of future GMST rise are reduced in our coupled simulations under RCP4.5 and RCP8.5 compared to uncoupled simulations. The patterns of meltwater-induced climate effects are not uniform, with reduced future warming over the Southern Ocean and enhanced warming in RCP8.5 over large parts of the Northern Hemisphere, especially by 2100.We project a global mean Antarctic contribution to sea level rise of 0.34 m by 2100 and 3.37 m by 2200 under RCP8.5, with 0.13 m by 2100 and 1.17 m by 2200 under RCP4.5 (Table 1). Patterns of sea level change are not spatially uniform and more heavily impacted locations vary based on the pattern of ice sheet mass loss. We find that the EAIS contribution to GMSLR over multi-century timescales rivals that of the WAIS and is even slightly higher than that from the WAIS under RCP8.5. Paleoclimate evidence shows signs of past ice sheet retreat in deep EAIS subglacial basins, while future model projections show differing responses. A recent review54 concluded that the EAIS has the potential to contribute substantially to GMSLR, particularly on multi-century timescales and under high emissions scenarios, as we find here. This also has implications for interpreting sources of sea level rise in the geologic past, which should not assume that the EAIS can only provide a substantial contribution after WAIS has lost all marine-based ice.Arctic temperatures are higher in the RCP8.5 coupled simulation than in the control before 2050 and for a multi-decade period centered around 2100. While this study is based on understanding the impact of a coupled AIS, this SAT response could drive enhanced ice loss on Greenland which could have significant impacts on subpolar North Atlantic deepwater formation and AMOC strength55. An important next step will be the addition of an interactively coupled Greenland ice sheet model.There is a wide spread of projections for the Antarctic contribution to sea level across models. ISMIP6 compared projections across 10 ice sheet models using standardized CMIP5 ocean and atmospheric forcing under RCP8.5 and RCP2.6. They find responses ranging from a sea level fall of 0.078 to a sea level rise of 0.3 m for RCP8.5 by 210056. The range of projected GMSLR contributions from the AIS as assessed in IPCC AR6 under SSP2-4.5 is 0.03-0.29 m at 2100 and -0.05-0.55 m at 21502,57. Our projected values under RCP4.5 of 0.13 m at 2100 and 0.55 m at 2150 (Table 1, Supplementary Table 1) are at the mid-range and upper end at each time period, respectively. For SSP5-8.5 the IPCC AR6 assessed range is 0.03–0.34 m at 2100 and -0.11–0.66 m at 2150 without deeply uncertain ice sheet processes like ice cliff collapse included, or 0.02–0.56 at 2100 and -0.11–3.68 when including uncertain ice sheet processes2,57. Our projected values under RCP8.5 of 0.34 m at 2100 and 1.45 m at 2150 place our results by 2100 at the upper end when comparing to a range that excludes uncertain ice sheet processes or in the middle of the range that includes uncertain processes while our values at 2150 are higher than the range that excludes uncertain processes and in the middle of the range that includes them. While these values are plausible and in line with the scientific consensus we note that this study is only using a single model and thus should be taken as one possibility of how future projections may evolve.Our study is one of several that have coupled ice sheet models to climate models. Park et al.29 interactively coupled the same dynamic ice sheet model used in our study (PSU3D) to an intermediate complexity climate model (LOVECLIM), finding that freshwater-induced suppression of atmospheric warming reduced Antarctic mass loss and GMSLR contributions through 2150, in line with our findings using a coupled general circulation model. Siahaan et al.30 used a different set of coupled models (BISICLES and UKESM) and found Antarctica contributed to a sea level fall by the end of their simulation period in 2100 under RCP8.5 due to increased snowfall exceeding mass loss. The study presented here differs from previous studies by providing a longer term simulation to 2200, including a radiative feedback analysis which allows for an assessment of the mechanisms behind delayed GMST rise, and offline coupling to a sea level model which allows for an assessment of the global sea level fingerprint that results from AIS mass loss. By including an ice sheet model that simulates hydrofracturing and ice-cliff calving, ice loss in our simulations is highly sensitive to evolving atmospheric conditions. This also tests the climate impacts and feedbacks resulting from a large meltwater flux to the Southern Ocean. More generally, our study complements previous work by assessing divergent climate-sea level responses of different sets of coupled models, highlighting the need to include dynamic ice sheets in more global climate models.The results presented here demonstrate the importance of embedding dynamic ice sheet models within Earth system models used for future climate, ice sheet, and sea level projections. They also highlight the global risks of Antarctic ice sheet instability under rising greenhouse gas emissions, underscoring the need to reduce emissions in the immediate near-term.MethodsModel descriptions and initializationThe climate model used is Community Earth System Model 1.2.2 with Community Atmospheric Model 5 atmospheric physics (CESM1-CAM5)31. CESM1.2 is a coupled global Earth system model containing interactive ocean, atmosphere, sea-ice, and land models linked via a coupler. The continent and ocean boundaries do not change in CESM1.2. CESM1.2 does not include fully interactive Greenland or Antarctic ice sheets58. It was run with 1° resolution for the ocean and sea-ice components and 0.9×1.25° resolution for the atmosphere and land components. The model grid has a displaced pole over Greenland. It is initialized with 20th century restart files. Simulations spanning the period from 2005-2200 and were conducted under Representative Concentration Pathway RCP8.5 and RCP4.559.The Antarctic ice sheet model used is the Penn State University ice sheet model (PSU3D)32,33. PSU3D is a three-dimensional ice sheet model that approximates ice flow using hybrid ice dynamics with an imposed parameterization of ice flux across the grounding line60, allowing for realistic simulation of grounding line retreat32. In these simulations it is run at a 10 km resolution with basal sliding coefficients obtained from an inverse run matching modeled surface elevations and observations61. Initial conditions were from DeConto et al.34, which included simulations using offline CESM1.2 forcing. Bed topographic boundary conditions use Bedmap262. We use CESM1.2 and PSU3D with Bedmap2 boundary conditions to make the best use of previously run control experiments.Models were run on the NCAR Cheyenne high performance computing system63. For the control scenarios, there is no freshwater forcing provided by the PSU3D ice sheet model. Testing determined that our RCP8.5 control matched the SAT evolution of the standard CMIP5 CESM1 simulation for RCP8.5, which is used for the time series in Fig. 364. For RCP4.5, data from CESM1-CAM5_rcp45_r1i1p1 obtained from the CMIP5 data repository was used as a control65. Preindustrial temperature data was obtained from the CMIP5 data repository66.Coupling methodologyCESM1.2 and PSU3D are run with an annual interactive coupling scheme allowing for a dynamic response of the ice sheet to changes in the climate model, and response of the climate system to ice sheet freshwater discharge. The annual coupling is accomplished as follows67. An initial climatology is used to force PSU3D for one model year (2005), provided from a standard CESM1.2 control simulation lacking additional meltwater forcing. The ice sheet model is then run for one model year to provide liquid water and solid ice discharge from the ice sheet, interpolated onto the CESM1.2 ocean grid at the nearest coastal ocean cell from where the mass loss occurs in the ice sheet. Latent heat is accounted for as solid ice melts. The ice sheet model internally determines which types of ice sheet discharge exit as a solid or liquid. Latent heat of the solid ice discharge phase change is accounted for in the climate model while latent heat for liquid fields is accounted for within the ice sheet model32. Latent heat from fields the ice sheet counts as liquid is accounted for within the ice sheet model. This may underestimate the delayed warming effect of ice sheet discharge on global climate; therefore, the extent of the delayed warming effect seen in this study should be taken as a lower bound. The fields the ice sheet model outputs as liquid melt components include ice sheet basal melt, sub-ocean ice face melt, percolation of meltwater to the base, and the counter effect of basal refreezing while the solid ice discharge forcing contains ice lost from calving and cliff failure. Liquid and solid discharge components enter the climate model at the surface ocean level55,68. While injecting freshwater at depth can lead to more mixing and a deeper mixed layer and work with other ocean models has shown the depth of freshwater input to have an effect in other models69, previous work with CESM indicates that there is little difference in CESM1-simulated ocean surface temperature, salinity, and sea-ice responses when freshwater is applied at depth versus in experiments where freshwater is added at the surface41. Following the calculation of interpolated liquid and solid ice sheet discharge, CESM1.2 is then run for one model year to obtain a meltwater-perturbed climatology. Ocean temperature at 400 m depth, 2 m surface air temperatures, and precipitation are then passed back to the ice sheet. The ice sheet model is built to intake ocean temperatures at 400 m as this depth level is representative of where warm deep water enters the Amundsen Sea Embayment70,71.Initial surface topography is provided to the climate sheet model by the ice sheet model at the first time step. At subsequent time steps, deviations between the input topography and evolving ice sheet topography are accommodated via lapse rate corrections for temperature and precipitation70. The fraction of input precipitation that falls as snow versus rain is parameterized based on the input surface air temperature. The ice sheet model surface mass balance calculations account for surface melting and refreezing as well as percolation of liquid water below the ice sheet surface layer. Surface melt is calculated via a positive degree day scheme, which calculates melt from the input temperature and precipitation, with melt beginning at -1°C based on observational relationships72.Ocean forcing of the ice sheetThe ocean melt rate parameterization is a quadratic function of the temperature difference between the nearest ocean grid cell and the depth-dependent freezing temperature which is defined as follows.$${{\rm{Ocean}}}\_{{\rm{melt}}}=({{K}} \; {{\rm{K}}}_{T\rho w}{{{\rm{C}}}}_{{{\rm{W}}}})/({L}_{f}\rho i)|{T}_{o}\,{{\rm{\hbox{-}}}}\,{T}_{f}|({T}_{o}\,{{\rm{\hbox{-}}}}\,{T}_{f})$$
                    (1)
                Where To is input 400 m ocean temperature, Tf is the freezing-point temperature at the base of the ice at a given depth, ρw and ρi are the densities of water and ice, cW is the specific heat of ocean water, Lf is the latent heat of fusion, KT is a transfer factor, and K is a set of tunable parameters32.This parameterization has been shown to be one of the best performing options for representing both integrated shelf melt and grounding line melt73. Melting at submerged vertical ice faces is calculated from the ocean melt rate of surrounding grid cells and increased by a scaling factor of 2 to better match observations. This scaling factor is lower than the scaling factor of 10 which was used in previous uncoupled ice sheet simulations34,70.To bring the ocean temperatures being passed to the ice sheet into closer agreement with observational values, the ocean temperature at 400 m is bias corrected using World Ocean Atlas 2018 observational temperatures74,75. As CESM1.2 does not have ocean cavities under ice shelves, ocean temperatures are taken from the static edge of the continent using a grid-cell-by-grid-cell stepping approach to determine the ocean temperature at the ice shelf edge wherever it is available in the ocean model. The ice sheet model interpolates them to the ice sheet grid and linearly extrapolates a value back into the interior of the shelf. To avoid a small number of warm grid cells from having an oversized impact on melt rates when interpolated over a large shelf, a single value is calculated as the average of all ocean grid cells in polygons specifying each ice shelf’s area and that one value is interpolated under that shelf. To bring melt rates in the Amundsen Sea region into closer alignment with observational values, a 2.5°C anomaly is added in that region, similar to the bias corrections applied in previous work with PSU3D34,70.Calving sensitivity and cliff failureAs in previous work with PSU3D, surface crevasse depth is influenced by surface melt and rainwater, assuming a quadratic relationship between meltwater production (R) and crevasse penetration depth (dw).$${d}_{w}={{\rm{CALVLIQ}}}{R}^{2}$$
                    (2)
                This meltwater enhanced crevassing (dw) influences ice shelf hydrofracturing and calving33,34. To bring mass loss from calving in line with observations over the modern period the CALVLIQ parameter is set to 35 m-1yr2.As used here, the ice sheet model accounts for enhanced calving at thick (O 1000 m) marine-terminating ice fronts that have lost their buttressing ice shelves, leaving tall subaerial ice cliffs prone to brittle failure76. Ice cliff calving occurs at calving fronts where the stresses exceed the yield strength. The cliff calving parameterization is applied as a horizontal wastage with a maximum rate of 7.7e3 m/y34. We note that the role of marine ice cliff calving in future Antarctic ice loss remains contested37,77, with much of the uncertainty caused by a lack of observations and poorly constrained physical properties of damaged glacial ice78,79.Model validationBefore the coupled run was integrated, several shorter tests were done under transient climate forcing from 2005-2020 to check for consistency between model results and existing observational measurements. The total modeled rate of basal melt around the continent from 2005-2017 is 1343.21 Gt/yr67, in alignment with rates from80 [1280-1628 Gt/yr] and81 [1010-1310 Gt/yr]. The total modeled calving rate over this period is 974.874 Gt/yr67, slightly below the estimate of 1177-1465 Gt/yr in ref. 80. The modeled basal melt rates at the Pine Island, Thwaites, Ross, and Ronne-Filchner ice shelves are 36.4, 35.1, 0.28, and 0.27 m/yr, respectively67 as compared to81 [14, 26.7, 0.3, 0.2 m/yr] and82 [16.2, 17.2, 0.3, 0.3 m/yr]. While modeled rates of ice loss are higher than the average observed melt rates at PIG and Thwaites, the total sea level rise contribution from the WAIS is in line with observations and areas of higher melt rates (up to 43 m/yr) have been seen at the Thwaites grounding line83. From 2005 to 2017, the total modeled AIS sea level rise contribution is 2 mm, lower than the 7.4 ± 1.5 mm Antarctic contribution reported for 1992–202011 implying that the coupled simulation is slightly underestimating sea level rise contributions during this observational period. The spatial patterns of changes in ice thickness from 2005 to 2020 compare well with observations from84 (their Fig. 1 compared to our Supplementary Fig. 1).Sea level rise calculationsGlobal mean sea level contributions are calculated using the modified volume above flotation (VAF) method which accounts for the rise or fall of bedrock elevation below grounded ice which changes VAF but does not alter sea level85.Geographically variable sea level changes accounting for gravitational, Earth rotational86 and Maxwell viscoelastic deformational87 effects are calculated by solving the sea level equation51,88. Calculations account for migrating shorelines and inundation of areas freed of marine grounded ice88,89. We adopt the finite volume sea level solver to solve the sea level equation on a global tetrahedral grid including 3D variations in Earth’s rheological structure35. We adopt the 3D viscosity structure and laterally varying lithospheric thickness model EM3D_L90 based on ANT-20 regional seismic tomography model91 in Antarctica and S362ANI global seismic tomography model92 across the rest of the globe. Lithosphere thickness in the model is based on93 over Antarctica and a global model94 elsewhere. Globally, the adopted computational grid has an average spatial (lateral and radial) resolution of 12 km from the surface to the Mohorovičić Discontinuity (MOHO), 25 km to 220 km depth, and 50 km to the core mantle boundary. The grid is regionally refined in Antarctica, with a resolution of 6 km to the base of the MOHO, 12 km to 220 km depth, and 25 km to 350 km depth36. The ice sheet model provides the initial topography in Antarctica, and this is merged with ETOPO2 elsewhere.Global energy budget analysisThe ocean heat uptake efficiency parameter (κ) and the radiative feedback parameter (λ) are calculated as:$$\kappa={dN}/{dT},\lambda=d(N-F)/{dT},$$
                    (3)
                Where dN is the global-mean net top of atmosphere radiation imbalance, dF is effective radiative forcing and dT is the global-mean near-surface air temperature change42. Based on the global-mean energy budget framework95,96, the transient global warming rate (dT/dt) can be approximated as:$${dT}/{dt}=({dF}/{dt})/(\kappa -\lambda )$$
                    (4)
                Where we substitute values of κ or λ from control or coupled simulations to isolate the impacts of ocean heat uptake efficiency or radiative feedback on the global warming rate42. Effective climate sensitivity is calculated as:$${{\rm{EffCS}}}=-{F}_{2x}/\lambda$$
                    (5)
                Where F2x represents the effective radiative forcing from a doubling of atmospheric carbon dioxide. The value of F2x in CESM1.2 is 3.88 Wm2 97. EffCS is an analog to equilibrium climate sensitivity except using λ from a transient state assuming λ remains constant until equilibrium42.Data visualizationSpatial sea level maps were created in ArcGIS using a Goode homolosine ocean-oriented projection10,98. Figures 1–3 and supplemental figures were created with Cartopy99. Sea level maps use country outlines provided by Natural Earth shapefiles: Pacific groupings, 1:10 m countries, 1:50 m Tiny Country Points. On some figures scientific colormaps are from100,101.

Data availability
              
              The climate data and spatial sea level mapping data generated in this study and referenced in the paper have been deposited in the University of Massachusetts Amherst ScholarWorks repository (https://doi.org/10.7275/6t64-wy56)102. The climate model data fields and spatial sea level data not referenced in this paper are available for non-commercial use from the corresponding authors due to difficulties hosting a large dataset externally. The ice sheet model data is available in the ScholarWorks repository (https://doi.org/10.7275/6t64-wy56)102. Data for the 1850-1900 baseline and CMIP5 RCP8.5 and RCP4.5 simulations are available from the Centre for Environmental Data Analysis64,65,66. Natural Earth country boundary data is available at www.naturalearthdata.com.
            Code availability
              
              CESM1.2 is available from the National Center for Atmospheric Research. The PSU3D code is available in the ScholarWorks repository102, please contact DP and RD for assistance running it. The 3D GIA model is available from the code’s developer Konstantin Latychev. Scripts for running the models and creating the figures are in the data repository (https://doi.org/10.7275/6t64-wy56).

items.title: FER 2 | PUBBLICATE LE GRADUATORIE DEL SECONDO BANDO
items.description: Il GSE ha pubblicato le graduatorie della seconda procedura competitiva per gli impianti a biogas, ai sensi del DM FER2. Riportiamo di seguito gli ult
items.body:
FER 2 | PUBBLICATE LE GRADUATORIE DEL SECONDO BANDO

28 Ottobre 2025

Il GSE ha pubblicato le graduatorie della seconda procedura competitiva per gli impianti a biogas, ai sensi del DM FER2.Riportiamo di seguito gli ulteriori dettagli contenuti nella comunicazione del GSE:Nella pagina Rinnovabili elettriche>accesso agli incentivi>Graduatorie FER2 sono consultabili:la graduatoria degli impianti risultati in posizione utile (Tabella A);gli elenchi degli impianti esclusi (Tabella B).Le richieste di accesso agli incentivi per gli impianti ammessi in Tabella A devono essere presentate tramite il Portale FER-E entro 30 giorni solari dalla data di entrata in esercizio, nei tempi previsti dal DM FER2 e dalle Regole Operative, pena l’applicazione del c.d. “fuori tempo“.Ai soggetti proponenti degli impianti esclusi in fase di formazione delle graduatorie, il GSE invierà una comunicazione specificando i motivi dell’esclusione.Per ulteriori informazioni è possibile consultare la sezione Rinnovabili elettriche / FER 2.

items.title: Ecomondo 2025, gli appuntamenti con Legambiente
items.description: Dal 4 al 7 novembre parteciperemo alla 28° edizione di Ecomondo, il punto di riferimento internazionale per la transizione ecologica e l’economia cir
items.body:
28 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

28 Ottobre 2025

Economia e sostenibilità

Transizione ecologica

Ecomondo 2025, gli appuntamenti con Legambiente

28 Ottobre 2025

Legambiente

28 Ottobre 2025

Economia e sostenibilità

Transizione ecologica

Dal 4 al 7 novembre parteciperemo alla 28° edizione di Ecomondo, il punto di riferimento internazionale per la transizione ecologica e l’economia circolare. Scopri i nostri appuntamenti in programma.
Ecomondo, il green technology expo a Fiera di Rimini dal 4 al 7 novembre, accenderà i riflettori su economia circolare, green e blue economy, riunendo aziende, ricercatori e istituzioni in un dialogo a livello internazionale. Oltre 200 gli appuntamenti in programma in cui approfondire i temi chiave della transizione ecologica.
Un appuntamento a cui non potevamo mancare e dove porteremo il nostro contributo organizzando diversi eventi per promuovere innovazione, tutela del territorio, buone pratiche ambientali ed economia circolare.
I nostri appuntamenti a Ecomondo 2025
 
Martedì 4 novembre 2025
Ore 14:00 – 15:30 Agorà Flaminia (Area Hall C1) – Ecomondo Presentazione del “Report Cave 2025” di Legambiente con il contributo di Fassa Bortolo.
Faremo un punto sui numeri delle attività estrattive in Italia: cave attive e dismesse, quantità di materiali estratti, canoni di concessione, quadro legislativo il tutto riassunto nel nuovo report Cave 2025 realizzato con il contributo di Fassa Bortolo. Al centro, le opportunità di recupero e riciclo dei materiali come motore di innovazione, occupazione e tutela del territorio verso l’economia circolare.
 
Mercoledì 5 novembre 2025
Ore 10:00 – 12:00 Sala Comunale, Palazzo del Turismo di Rimini (Piazzale Fellini 3):
Conferenza stampa finale del Progetto europeo Life Muscles, che si pone come obiettivo quello di contribuire alla riduzione dell’impatto provocato dalla dispersione nell’ambiente marino delle retine utilizzate negli allevamenti di mitilico. A seguire la visita all’impianto mobile di riciclo delle calze per la mitilicoltura.
Ore 14:00 – 18:00 Sala Tulipano – Padiglione B6 (ingresso est) – Ecomondo
Workshop internazionale del Progetto Life Muscles
Ore 14:30 – 16:00 Padiglione D1 – Agorà Ariminum A (Circular Economy) – Ecomondo:
Convegno “Riciclo dei prodotti assorbenti per la persona: verso la responsabilità estesa del produttore – stato dell’arte e prospettive”: i risultati della prima ricerca sul mercato sulle abitudini e sull’interesse dei consumatori verso il riciclo dei prodotti assorbenti per la persona (AHP);  si tratterà il tema della raccolta differenziata, della sostenibilità e della Responsabilità Estesa del Produttore (EPR).
 
Giovedì 6 novembre 2025
Ore 12:00 – 13:00 Circular Lab Arena (Hall B2) – Ecomondo:
Presentazione del V Atlante delle Foreste, realizzato da Legambiente e AzzeroCO2 con il supporto tecnico di Compagnia delle Foreste per Il Sole 24 Ore. Un quadro aggiornato sullo stato delle foreste italiane e sul loro ruolo strategico nella transizione ecologica.
Ore 16:30 Stand Confagricoltura, Padiglione D3 (n.104-205) – Ecomondo:
Consegna del Premio “Comunità Forestali Sostenibili 2025”, promosso da PEFC Italia e Legambiente alle migliori buone pratiche di gestione territoriale e forestale delle aree montane. Realtà e storie capaci di mettere al centro la sostenibilità ambientale, la qualità delle foreste e del territorio montano, ma anche prodotti e servizi di origine forestale.
Programma completo delle iniziative su www.ecomondo.com

items.title: Allarme Onu su crisi climatica, serve un’azione globale per la COP30
items.description:
L’ultimo rapporto di sintesi sugli NDC delle Nazioni Unite svela un pericoloso divario tra parole e azioni
The post Allarme Onu su crisi climatica, se
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Le politiche globali per ridurre le emissioni di gas serra non sono riuscite a colmare il divario tra ambizione e attuazione, nonostante i progressi evidenti in alcuni settori. Questo l’allarme suonato dall’ultimo rapporto di sintesi sugli NDC (Contributi determinati a livello nazionale) delle Nazioni Unite. Si tratta di un documento pubblicato dalla Convenzione quadro delle Nazioni Unite sui cambiamenti climatici (UNFCCC) che valuta l’impatto collettivo dei piani climatici nazionali dei Paesi, noti come contributi determinati a livello nazionale. Il documento rileva che gli attuali piani climatici nazionali, se attuati integralmente, potrebbero portare a una riduzione delle emissioni inferiore a un terzo di quella necessaria per evitare pericolosi cambiamenti climatici entro il 2035. La riduzione prevista del 19-24% rispetto ai livelli del 2019 è molto lontana dal calo del 60% al 2035. Obiettivo necessario per limitare il riscaldamento globale entro 1,5 °C di aumento della temperatura globale rispetto all’era pre-industriale, previsto dall’Accordo di Parigi ed evitare gli effetti più gravi della crisi climatica. Le richieste del WWF In vista della COP30, il WWF chiede un piano di risposta globale che possa portare il mondo verso l’obiettivo 1,5 °C. Bisogna limitare al massimo la possibilità di superamento di tale soglia che costringerebbe a sforzi titanici per tornare indietro. Vanno affrontate quindi le questioni relative all’energia, alle emissioni di metano, alle foreste, all’industria pesante e va garantita una transizione equa. La presidenza brasiliana dovrà guidare i Paesi verso una risposta di questo tipo per rafforzare il multilateralismo e gli sforzi globali volti a ridurre le emissioni nell’ambito degli accordi sul clima. Ancora grande il divario tra parole e azioni Il WWF rileva che sebbene molti Paesi stiano compiendo progressi concreti, il divario tra parole e azioni rimane pericolosamente grande. “È particolarmente deludente che, invece di dare l’esempio, le principali economie del G20 non abbiano ancora presentato i loro obiettivi a meno di due settimane dall’inizio della COP30 –ha dichiarato Mariagrazia Midulla, responsabile Clima ed Energia del WWF Italia. – Tra tutti, spicca il fatto che l’Unione Europea non abbia ancora presentato il suo NDC, dal momento che la decisione è rimpallata tra Ministri dell’Ambiente e i Capi di Stato e di Governo”. “Ora la parola finale la dovrebbero dire i Ministri dell’Ambiente il 4 Novembre, a pochi giorni dall’apertura del Summit dei Leader e della COP: speriamo che l’Europa non voglia perdere una delle principali leve che ancora può guadagnare: l’autorevolezza di chi crea l’economia decarbonizzata, invece di arrancare solo per recuperare terreno. Per una transizione energetica equa, occorre mantenere gli impegni della COP28, cioè ‘transitare fuori dai combustibili fossili’, almeno triplicare le fonti rinnovabili e raddoppiare il risparmio energetico. Il mondo non può permettersi ritardi mascherati da diplomazia”, conclude Midulla. Nonostante le lacune che permangono in termini di ambizione e risultati, il WWF è incoraggiato dalla conclusione della relazione secondo cui un numero maggiore di Paesi ha incluso una gamma più ampia di misure relative alle foreste. I Paesi devono partire da questo risultato alla COP30 e definire i prossimi passi del loro impegno esistente per conservare, proteggere e ripristinare la natura e gli ecosistemi. Obiettivi da raggiungere anche attraverso l’arresto e l’inversione della deforestazione e del degrado forestale entro il 2030.

items.title: Bracconaggio selvaggio nella Piana di Gela
items.description:
Denuncia WWF: nonostante i vincoli, in quest'area della Sicilia i cacciatori non rispettano le limitazioni e sfidano la legge con arroganza
The post B
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie La videodenuncia delle Guardie WWF Nei giorni scorsi a Gela (Caltanissetta) le Guardie venatorie WWF hanno presentato un video-denuncia sul bracconaggio nella Piana di Gela dove la caccia è diventata – secondo il WWF – un vero far west nonostante l’area sia classificata di importanza internazionale per la tutela dell’avifauna. In particolare, nonostante i regimi di protezione che insistono sull’area e gli specifici divieti all’attività venatoria che la Regione ha imposto nella Piana, qui i cacciatori non rispettano tali limitazioni e sfidano la legge con arroganza. Il video girato durante il servizio Nello scorso 21 settembre – quando, secondo il Calendario venatorio 2025/26, la caccia nella Piana di Gela era assolutamente vietata essendo classificata come IBA (Important Bird and Biodiversity Area) – le Guardie WWF si sono recate nelle campagne costiere per un servizio di vigilanza antibracconaggio, cercano di far rispettare il divieto per tutelare gli uccelli migratori protetti dall’UE. Le immagini registrate in tale occasione dalle Guardie venatorie WWF – brevi ma significative – danno l’esatta idea del far west in un giorno di “silenzio venatorio”. A Manfria (Gela), pochi minuti dopo l’alba, tra le case di villeggiatura del borgo marinaro vagano tranquillamente, armati di fucile, tre cacciatori. Le Guardie WWF intervengono e subito il primo cacciatore si dà alla fuga, non prima di aver avvisato gli altri cacciatori che si dileguano. Ne segue un fuggi-fuggi generale di auto “imboscate” tra i campi che viene filmato dalle Guardie. A Desusino (Butera), una dozzina di cacciatori con numerosi cani al seguito si trova tranquillamente a caccia di conigli tra i binari della linea ferrata sul terrapieno che costeggia la strada statale 115. Dunque in condizione di gravissimo pericolo per la sicurezza dei trasporti e la pubblica e privata incolumità. Anche in questo caso il video documenta l’arrogante reazione dei cacciatori che, invece di rispettare l’alt delle Guardie, si danno alla rocambolesca fuga attraversando i binari, per raggiungere due furgoni – precedentemente parcheggiati lontano dalle strade, imboscati in un vigneto abbandonato – con cui si dileguano in direzioni opposte. Un’astuzia – individuata grazie ai droni utilizzati dagli operatori del WWF – per ostacolare l’eventuale inseguimento e per confondere le Guardie. Un contesto di illegalità diffusa In altre occasioni il personale di vigilanza del WWF ha riscontrato la presenza di “vedette” che allertano i cacciatori appena individuano il veicolo delle Guardie. Il coordinamento avviene con apposite chat.Non si tratta, dunque, di episodi marginali di inosservanza di qualche trascurabile regola sulla disciplina della caccia, ma di fenomeni criminosi, di attività illecite in danno al patrimonio faunistico dello Stato. Esiste anche un pericolo per la sicurezza dei cittadini, monopolio del territorio in un contesto di diffusa illegalità, dove ruolo e funzioni dei pubblici ufficiali deputati alla vigilanza ambientale e antibracconaggio sono inefficaci. Nell’area della Piana di Gela vi sono diverse aree protette e vincoli di tutela (per un totale di 36.000 ettari), istituiti dalle Autorità regionali, nazionali e comunitarie proprio per l’importanza di tale territorio in termini di biodiversità, rotte migratorie dell’avifauna, emergenze faunistiche. Oltre 400 i cacciatori autorizzati, per 4 Guardie volontarie WWF. Violazioni amministrative contestate dalle Guardie WWF nella Piana di Gela nel mese di luglio 2025 (attività abusiva di addestramento cani prima dell’apertura della caccia): 9Cacciatori identificati dalle Guardie WWF in attività venatoria nella Piana di Gela in periodo di divieto di caccia: 7Bracconieri denunciati all’Autorità Giudiziaria per esercizio abusivo della caccia nella Piana di Gela nel solo mese di settembre: 3 Stop caccia selvaggia Il Governo vuole stravolgere le regole sulla caccia: la petizione WWF chiede di aumentare le tutele per la fauna, non le libertà per chi imbraccia le doppiette Aderisci all'appello

items.title: Environmental treaties are paralysed — here’s how we can do better
items.body:
COMMENT
                28 October 2025

Environmental treaties are paralysed — here’s how we can do better

The collapse of talks about a UN plastics treaty is the wake-up call we didn’t need. It’s time to study what is going wrong and why.
                
            
        
        
            
                By

Rakhyun E. Kim ORCID: http://orcid.org/0000-0002-1308-68490 & 
    
        
        
            
                Peter Bridgewater ORCID: http://orcid.org/0000-0001-7972-53861

Rakhyun E. Kim
                
                
                    
                        
                            Rakhyun E. Kim is an associate professor of Earth System Governance at the Copernicus Institute of Sustainable Development, Utrecht University, Utrecht, The Netherlands.
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        
                            View author publications
                            
                                
                                    Search author on:
                                    PubMed
                                     Google Scholar
                                    
                            
                       
                    
                
            
        
            
                
                    Peter Bridgewater
                
                
                    
                        
                            Peter Bridgewater is an adjunct professor in terrestrial and marine biodiversity governance at the Centre for Applied Water Science, Institute for Applied Ecology, University of Canberra, Australia. 
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        
                            View author publications
                            
                                
                                    Search author on:
                                    PubMed
                                     Google Scholar

Twitter
            
        
    
    
        
            Facebook
            
        
    
    
        
            Email

Artist Benjamin Von Wong’s installation sat outside the United Nations building in Geneva during negotiations for the plastics treaty in August.  Credit: Orjan Ellingvag/Alamy

On 15 August in Geneva, Switzerland, a fifth round of negotiations towards a multilateral treaty on reducing plastic pollution collapsed. The chair announced that the committee had concluded its work — without producing a draft treaty. Governments had failed to agree on the proposed articles of the convention; no further negotiations were being suggested.This failure reveals a weakness in all environmental treaty negotiations, whether new or existing ones: a consensus-driven process waters down action to the lowest common denominator. Only symptoms get addressed, not causes.Heatwaves linked to carbon emissions from specific companiesThe result is much action without impact. Yet this ineffective method continues — a situation we characterize as ‘institutional paralysis’. What’s needed is to make international organizations capable of imagining and doing things differently. That requires more research on politics and governance, and that institutions make better use of the knowledge generated by that research.To overcome this paralysis, at least in the environmental arena, we propose establishing a standing process, mandated by governments, to evaluate the state of global environmental treaties and related bodies. Its role would be to assess their fitness, both individually and collectively; identify what is and is not working and why; and provide actionable recommendations to the United Nations for reforming them.Frozen institutionsInternational environmental institutions resemble deer frozen in headlights: acutely aware of an impending crisis, yet incapable of meaningful movement. The UN Framework Convention on Climate Change elevates urgency, but even implementing its current pledges fully would fall short of avoiding dangerous climate change1. The Convention on Biological Diversity sets ambitious conservation targets for protected areas, yet expanding the zones offers little defence against an intensifying local and global extinction of species caused by climate change2.These are not merely failures of ambition. They are design flaws. The implementation of existing policies, however robust, is insufficient to confront the scale and complexity of today’s polycrisis3.States now have a legal duty to prevent climate harm — justice is in reachThe result is institutional paralysis: a persistent incapacity of environmental institutions to act, adapt or achieve stated objectives despite sustained procedural activity. Like the Red Queen in Alice through the Looking Glass, paralysed institutions run in place just to stay put. Trapped in cycles of action without impact, movement persists but purpose dissolves.The rational response to paralysis would be to acknowledge it and seek support. Yet most institutions resort to symbolic gestures to maintain the appearance of relevance. In July in Zimbabwe, after months of discussions, the Ramsar Convention on Wetlands agreed on a strategic plan that mostly reaffirmed 20-year-old decisions. The International Whaling Commission projects the illusion of progress, framing resolved issues such as widespread whaling as ongoing to justify the body’s continued activity4.Others choose to gamble. The London Convention and its 1996 Protocol on marine pollution have opened the door to marine geoengineering, including fertilization of the ocean with iron to stimulate phytoplankton growth and, increasingly, measures to enhance ocean alkalinity to increase carbon dioxide absorption5. Although such interventions would carry huge, clearly identified risks to the marine environment, they are still being considered as potential responses to climate change.This reflects a broader dynamic: institutions are navigating trade-offs between various risks, in ways that endanger the very object that they seek to conserve, and undermine their own effectiveness in saving it.Diagnosing institutional paralysisInstitutional paralysis arises when organizations are confronted with circumstances that exceed their original purpose, authority or capability. Take, for example, climate change. Today’s climate is in much worse shape than when the UN Framework Convention on Climate Change was adopted in 1992, arguably exceeding the body’s capacity to manage responses. Scientific knowledge about our planet is abundant and expanding and institutions are increasingly overloaded with information.Why the green-technology race might not save the planetGroups of scientists have tried to issue ‘warnings to humanity’6, but after initial brief attention, the warnings go unheeded. And concerns are spiralling faster than UN conventions can keep up with. For example, the study of climate change involves not only the natural sciences, but also, increasingly, social sciences — adding further angles, such as justice, to the discussions7. Yet deteriorating social issues are an outcome of the acceleration of global warming, which further stretches the climate agenda. Ineffectiveness then breeds more problems, while resources remain stagnant. As a result, public confidence in the climate convention erodes, reinforcing the sense of paralysis.Already-overburdened institutions are also strained by accelerating anthropogenic pressures that fall outside their mandates. Today, much of this spillover stems from climate change8. For example, the World Heritage Convention lists 51 marine sites in its protected areas, including 29 coral reefs — which looks good on paper. However, it lacks the authority to address climate-driven threats to coral reefs, such as ocean warming and acidification. Although there is a great deal of science available to assist with evaluating impacts on heritage, geopolitical realities hold more sway on which sites are accepted and added to the list9.The complex reasons why institutions tread water are revealing. Limited capacity is one factor. Most international environmental institutions are chronically under-resourced10. Climate change is often more politically salient than biodiversity and tends to receive most of the funding11. For example, the Cali Fund for supporting the sharing of genetic resources, which was launched amid excitement in February at the resumed 16th biodiversity Conference of the Parties (COP16) in Rome, is struggling to reach its targets.Ministers met in May to set directions for negotiations at COP30 in Brazil in November.Credit: Mads Claus Rasmussen/Ritzau Scanpix/AFP via GettyGeopolitical dynamics further exacerbate the problem of fundraising for the conventions, and tend to favour climate over biodiversity, despite the nexus between them. The behaviours of major powers such as the United States, Russia, China and the European Union shape outcomes of multilateral negotiations. Sometimes, countries with economies that rely heavily on oil and natural gas act as deliberate blockers. Contestation between countries with different socio-economic and political circumstances also deepens institutional paralysis.Even when they lack capacity and resources, most institutions continue to project an image of progress and preserve the appearance of hope rather than acknowledge failure and close. Like all entities composed of people, they are inherently political. Admitting the failure of institutions into which so much has been invested, without viable replacements, is seen as carrying too great a political (and psychological) risk.Many institutions are also entrenched in the ecomodernist paradigm12; they often choose to pursue technological fixes, such as carbon capture or extensive monoculture afforestation, as the path of least resistance. Yet such fixes often lead to more problems.

items.title: Ancora due Ibis eremita uccisi a fucilate
items.description:
I due uccelli facevano parte del progetto LIFE20 Ibis eremita, finanziato dall’Unione Europea
The post Ancora due Ibis eremita uccisi a fucilate appea
items.body: In evidenza Il Panda Siamo Noi In evidenza Il leopardo delle Nevi In evidenza Adotta una specie Il bracconaggio continua a decimare una specie vicina all’estinzione Due Ibis eremita (Geronticus eremita), appartenenti ad una specie in pericolo critico di estinzione — scomparsi in Europa nel XVII secolo e reintrodotti grazie a un progetto di conservazione LIFE riconosciuto a livello mondiale — sono stati abbattuti il 16 ottobre a Dubino (Provincia di Sondrio, Lombardia), poco dopo aver attraversato il confine durante la migrazione. Un intervento immediato da parte delle autorità è stato possibile grazie alla stretta collaborazione tra l’associazione Waldrappteam, che gestisce il progetto, i Carabinieri Forestali e la Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola.I due Ibis, Zoppo e Zaz, facevano parte del progetto LIFE20 Ibis eremita, che vede Natura Viva come suo unico partner italiano ed è finanziato dall’Unione Europea. Si tratta infatti della prima iniziativa al mondo volta a ristabilire una specie migratrice nel suo storico areale europeo, ripristinando un comportamento migratorio culturale ormai perduto. Dal 2004, giovani Ibis allevati dall’uomo vengono guidati dalle colonie riproduttive che si trovano a nord delle Alpi fino al sito di svernamento in Toscana (Oasi WWF di Orbetello), assicurando che imparino la rotta migratoria per i viaggi futuri. La storia dei due Ibis Zoppo era un pionere tra questi uccelli. Nel 2017 aveva seguito con successo un ultraleggero da Überlingen, attraversando le Alpi fino all’Italia. Nel 2020 era diventato il primo Ibis eremita sessualmente maturo, dopo oltre 400 anni, a tornare indipendentemente nel sito di riproduzione sul Lago di Costanza. Un traguardo di inestimabile importanza per la creazione di una nuova colonia europea. Zaz, nata in natura a Überlingen nel maggio 2025, stava imparando quest’anno la rotta migratoria proprio da Zoppo — seguendolo passo dopo passo nel suo primo viaggio verso sud. All’inizio di ottobre 2025, la coppia aveva lasciato il sito riproduttivo ed era entrata in Svizzera, tentando più volte di attraversare le Alpi nel Cantone dei Grigioni. Il 16 ottobre, erano finalmente riusciti a superare la dorsale alpina principale nei pressi del Piz Gallagiun, a quasi 3.000 metri di altitudine. Poco dopo, si erano posati in un prato nei pressi di Dubino per cercare cibo — e sono stati uccisi a fucilate meno di un’ora dopo essere entrati in Italia. Petizione caccia Firma anche tu per dire Stop alla caccia selvaggia Aderisci all'appello Quasi tutti gli Ibis eremita del Progetto sono equipaggiati di trasmettitori GPS, che ne consentono il monitoraggio in tempo reale. Ciò ha permesso a Waldrappteam di allertare immediatamente le autorità. I Carabinieri Forestali di Lecco e Sondrio, con il supporto della Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola, hanno avviato un’indagine approfondita e recuperato i trasmettitori dei due Ibis. Sono stati sequestrati armi, munizioni, dispositivi elettronici ed una licenza di caccia ad un sospettato, che ora dovrà rispondere di accuse tra cui uccisione di fauna protetta e possesso illegale di armi. Ibis eremita in volo Il bracconaggio mette a rischio specie già minacciate Dure condanne arrivano anche dai vertici del mondo della conservazione.“Il bracconaggio resta la minaccia più grave per l’Ibis eremita in Italia,”ha affermato il Dr. Johannes Fritz, Direttore di Waldrappteam Conservation & Research. “L’uccisione di due Ibis eremita a meno di un’ora dal loro arrivo in Italia è un promemoria doloroso della grave minaccia che il bracconaggio rappresenta per la biodiversità e dell’urgenza di combattere questo crimine.”L’episodio avviene in un momento di forte preoccupazione riguardo al Disegno di Legge 1552, una proposta legislativa italiana che mira ad estendere la stagione venatoria anche a periodi cruciali per le specie migratrici.Un grazie ai Carabinieri Forestali ed alla Riserva Naturale Pian di Spagna e Lago di Mezzola per la loro azione rapida e professionale. Questo caso evidenzia l’importanza della collaborazione coordinata tra organizzazioni di conservazione, forze dell’ordine, autorità e volontari — in linea con l’Articolo 9 della Costituzione italiana, che impegna la Repubblica a proteggere la natura e la biodiversità per le generazioni future.

items.title: Ge Vernova: indicazioni geografiche ed operative per evento di Green Team Building a Lucera (FG)
items.description: Gentilissimi Partecipanti all‘evento di team building, questa pagina è pensata per fornirvi tutti i dettagli tecnici sull’attività che and
items.body:
Ge Vernova: indicazioni geografiche ed operative per evento di Green Team Building a Lucera (FG)

27.10.2025

condividi:

Gentilissimi Partecipanti all'evento di team building, questa pagina è pensata per fornirvi tutti i dettagli tecnici sull'attività che andremo a realizzare. Le attività di Team Building, promosse da Rete Clima, sono progettate per favorire la crescita delle foreste italiane e della biodiversità. Un modo concreto per dimostrare l’impegno verso la responsabilità ambientale, dando corpo alle strategie aziendali ESG.

In aggiunta a quanto specificato di seguito, per qualunque necessità o approfondimento ci possiamo sentire tramite email o telefono (contatti in fondo alla pagina).

Indicazioni generali

Quando: 2 dicembre 2025 - con data di backup in caso di mal tempo fissata per il giorno 16 dicembre (stesso orario).

Dove: ritrovo alle ore 10:30 presso l'area adiacente alla Masseria Sant'Agapito - A Rural Odyssey, dove vi accoglierà il personale di Rete Clima: vedi Link Google Maps

Iscrizione all'evento: clicca qui per iscriverti

Programma

saluti e introduzione alle attività forestali: illustrazione delle corrette tecniche forestali per la piantagione degli alberi, distribuzione DPI (guanti da lavoro) e dei materiali di lavoro;

Avvio delle attività;

Conclusione dei lavori, chiusura dell'evento e saluti.

Raccomandazioni

Abbigliamento: comodo/sportivo, con scarpe robuste o sportive, meglio se da trekking. Utile preparare un "abbigliamento aziendale", con magliette, cappellini, grembiuli e altri capi personalizzati con il logo aziendale.

Campagna nazionale Foresta Italia: SDGs raggiunti e Patrocini

Di seguito i riferimenti relativi alle attività forestali che svolgeremo insieme:

L'attività è svolta nell'ambito della nostra Campagna forestale nazionale Foresta Italia®.

Contatti Team Rete Clima:

Diego Scaglia: 339 4995893 - diego.scaglia@reteclima.it
